statement.tex: \text{Differentiate the following } \\ \quad f(x) = e^{x^3} \\ \text{with respect to x.}\\

step.tex: \text{The domain of f(x) is }\mathbb{R}. \\ \text{In other words, x can be anything.}
step.reason: \text{There is no restriction on x.} e^{\text{anything}}\text{ can be}\\ \text{evaluated. But why bother with finding the}\\ \text{domain? Because if f(x) is not defined for some x, }\\ \text{then how can }f'(x)\text{ be?}
\text{The above is a simply the application of the}\\ \textbf{Chain Rule} - f(x) = (g\circ h)(x) \implies f'(x) = \frac{dg}{dh}\cdot\dfrac{dh}{dx}.
